summary: This document is an email chain from September 5, 2019, discussing federal statute of limitation reform for child sexual abuse crimes in the wake of the Jeffrey Epstein and Larry Nassar cases. It includes an op-ed by Theresa Covington calling for a federal Child Victims Act and highlights institutional failures.

events.title: Epstein's non-prosecution agreement
events.description: A lenient federal non-prosecution agreement resulted in Epstein serving only 13 months in jail with work release, wiping clean more serious charges.

events.title: New York passes Child Victims Act
events.description: New York State passed the Child Victims Act, extending statutes of limitations for sex crimes and allowing victims to file civil suits until age 55.

keyFacts: The email discusses the need for federal statute of limitation reform for child sexual abuse crimes, inspired by state-level changes like New York's Child Victims Act.
The attached op-ed cites the Jeffrey Epstein and Larry Nassar cases as examples of institutional failures that allowed abuse to continue.
Epstein's 2008 non-prosecution agreement is specifically noted as overly lenient, resulting in only 13 months of jail time with work release.
The correspondence is between officials at Safe Horizon, a victim services organization, and indicates policy advocacy work on behalf of abuse survivors.
The document highlights a one-year window in New York (as of 2019) allowing victims to bring lawsuits for molestation that occurred before the Child Victims Act was passed.
